awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Enabling Large-Scale Manufacturing of Organic Electronic Devices Using Photolithography
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a photoresist system that is compatible with a much wider range of materials than traditional photoresists, allowing for the patterning of advanced semiconducting polymers and small molecules on existing photolithographic equipment. Through Phase I project, Orthogonal has improved its fluorinated photoresist system by making two new materials with lower manufacturing cost and enhanced performance. In this Phase II project, the patterning of the widely used conductive polymer poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene):poly(styrene sulfonic acid) (PEDOT:PSS) and similar acidic materials will be studied. Multiple approaches will be taken to continuously improve the performance of the new photoresist materials. The scalability of one or both photoresist materials to large quantities will be investigated by addressing the major issues that may be challenging to the scale-up, including dealing with heat generation and finding a suitable initiator.

The broader/commercial impacts of this project will be the potential to enable the large-scale manufacturing of organic electronic devices by leveraging the existing photolithographic infrastructure currently used in the industry. The availability of the new photoresist materials in large quantities and consistent quality will help meet the performance and volume demands of organic electronic industry, which is expected to grow rapidly once a scalable and high-yield manufacturing technique is available.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Orthogonal has developed a unique set of chemicals that addresses the crucial OLED display manufacturing issue facing major display companies such as Samsung, LG and Sharp. Orthogoanl's products will enable manufacturers to make high resolution OLED displays using their existing infrastructure as well as large area displays for TV and signage applications. OLED respresents the future of displays and will be used for smart phones, TV, and virtual reality (VR), as well as many other applications. It's advantages include thin, light weight, flexible and colorful images that are superior to tradition liquid crystal (LCD) displays.

OLED manufacturing today faces many challenges since the tradtional technique of photolithography is not compatible with the chemically sensitive OLED materials. The alternative techniques have limitations with resolution and large size patterning which makes them uncompetitive with LCD in the market. Orthogonal makes breakthrough chemicals, developed during this NSF project, that allow for these same display companies to use photolithography to make OLED displays, greatly enhancing the resolution and area achievable. For new markets like VR, this is especially important, because high resolution is a key factor for true immersion into the virtual environment. For smart phones, improvements to resolution and lifetime will have significant impacts for the user. Yield improvements in TV manufacturing will drive down the costs and make them easier to commercialize. A demonstration of this technology (primary image) was developed during this project to prove its efficacy.

Orthogonal's technology comes out of Cornell university and uses environmentally friendly, and OLED compatible, chemicals as the basis for a new photolithographic process. The photoresist system (a pattern of which can be seen in the secondary image) was developed to provide high resolution and to be easy to use in the current infrastructure.

Manufacturers can immediately adopt this technology since it does not require major new investments in infrastructure, a distinct advantage over new techniques such as inkjet printing which require new equipment to be purchased.

Orthogonal is enabling an information rich environment and new experiences for end consumers and represents the shortest path for display manufacturers to revitalize and expand their business.


Last Modified: 05/03/2016
Modified by: John Defranco

Images (1 of )
  • High resolution 3-color OLED demo created using the Orthogonal photolithographic patterning technique. The resolution and fill factor for the pixels is state of the art, but not at the limits of the technology.
    Orthogonal, Inc.

    John Defranco
    600ppi OLED Display Demo
